Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Module-Centric Approach to Integrated Adaptation of Assembly Products and Supply Chains

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award is to develop new modeling methodologies for concurrent product assembly module design and supplier selection. Such methodologies will support quick and efficient adaptation of product assembly modules for high product variety, and allow identification of key interrelation between product module re-configurations and supply chain performance. The approach of this research is to develop three methods and integrate them: (1) graph theory based assembly representation method incorporating product and supply-chain information, (2) subassembly generation method by hierarchical multi-layer assembly decomposition, and (3) mathematical models for linking subassembly modules with suppliers for supply chain efficiency using multi-objective computation methods. Case studies will be conducted jointly by participating universities and industry partners in order to validate the above methods. Deliverables of this research include mathematical models, heuristics algorithms, software and materials for education and technology transfer.

The success of this research project will transform assembly decomposition and supply chain design from disjointed processes into an integrated decision-making process, providing a more holistic view of the manufacturing enterprise and its all value stream partners. The graph-theoretic assembly representation and decomposition methods will provide innovative ways to model and plan assembly products more effectively, and will increase the level of concurrent engineering. These enhanced modeling capabilities and decision making tools will help minimize unnecessary lengthy iterations between the design department and suppliers, and improve U.S. manufacturing competitiveness by helping bring products to the market rapidly at reduced cost. The developed methodologies and models can lead to software systems and information technology infrastructure useful to industry. The education program will promote learning, teaching and transfer of new technologies to industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project successfully developed new models and algorithms for the integrated planning of assembly products and supply chains, and helps increase the efficiency and competitiveness of manufacturing companies.

Ineffective, uncoordinated assembly planning has hurt the efficiency of many manufacturing companies. Almost all products are made by assembling components and modules. The planning of the assembly consists of complex steps and decisions, including partitioning a product into subassemblies and modules, organizing supply chains for distributed production, collaborating with suppliers for production, and finally assembling the components and sub-assemblies. The assembly plan should also seek minimal cost, superior quality and short leadtime. Although the assembly planning involves many interwoven decisions on the product structure, assembly processes and supply chains, each decision is often made in isolation from other decisions due to the lack of scientific integrated methodologies. This deficiency often makes the manufactures suffer from unnecessary cost increase, delayed product development, and low supply-chains performance.

The long-range goal of this research project was to establish a scientific foundation and develop novel methodologies for the product assembly. The specific objectives were to (1) establish fundamental integrated mathematical models enabling concurrent product module organization and supply chain planning, and (2) identify the key interrelation between product module configurations and supply chain performance by using the integrative models.

This research project achieved the goal by creating and advancing the related models and algorithms. This project provided the theory and models on how to plan the structure of a product assembly.

First, new graph theoretic models were created to represent the multi-level hierarchical subassembly structure and subassembly groups for a product. The new representation models can express logically how the components are grouped to define subassemblies and how these subassemblies are grouped again to define bigger subassemblies. The new representation models can also incorporate supply chain information such as cost, leadtime and possible suppliers. The models provide the foundation to represent product structure mathematically.

Second, new mathematical models and algorithms were also developed to systematically partition a product into the subassemblies of multi-level hierarchical structure. The mathematical models allow the assignment of each component to the correct subassemblies of multiple levels throughout the hierarchical subassembly structure. The developed efficient algorithms enable the product partitioning to consider important information on the product assembly such as cost, leadtime or suppliers. The models and algorithms can find the best assembly plan for cost saving, quality improvement, leadtime decrease, or subassembly inventory reduction. The models and algorithms offer effective ways to determine an assembly structure.

Third, new mathematical models were derived to describe the fundamental relations between the assembly decomposition and supply chain performance. In particular, the new mathematical models reveal the impact of the product variety on the inventory levels of subassemblies. The models also show the fundamental relation of the assembly sequence and the subassembly inventory levels. The models also prove why delayed differentiation strategies in industry work for the inventory level reduction even for a complex product.

This research project advances scientific knowledge and methodologies for the product assembly. The mathematical models and algorithms integrate product module planning, manufacturing operation sequencing and supply chain management. Thus, the models and algorithms can transform separated unorganized decision problems into an integrated problem. The new multi-layered graph-theoretic assembly representations provide a new foundation to express the assembly and subassembly structure. The algorithms offer efficient methods to compute for the best assembly structure and plans. The theoretical models deepen the understanding of the impact of the assembly structure on the product and supply chain performance.

This research project provides broader impacts to the related scientific fields and industry. The new models and methods can be applied to many research problems in product design and supply chain. The general structure of the problems and models opens the potential to be developed further for a wide range of other decomposition and aggregation problems. The integrated decision-making models will help the industry practitioners to find better solutions for assembly planning and supply chain management. The developed models and algorithms have the potential to be implemented as new software and serve information infrastructure for industry. Thus this research project will contribute to regaining the competitiveness of the US manufacturing.
